title: Shimano finally extends Cues to drop bar bikes
content:
Cyclist
Shimano finally extends Cues to drop bar bikes

It could be the longest wait in road cycling, but Shimano has announced the launch of its Cues components for drop bar bikes, two years after they were introduced for flat bars and almost three after their first appearance in an e-bike specific 10- and 11-speed drivetrain.

Cues is a replacement for all Shimano’s groupsets with 9-11 speeds, including its Tiagra, Sora and Claris road bike groupsets plus 11-speed 105.

The new drop bar Cues groupset components include shifters, double chainring 50/34t and 46/32t cranksets, single chainring 42t and 40t cranksets and a flat mount hydraulic disc brake. In addition, there’s a 2×10/9-speed front derailleur and a short rear derailleur designed to provide more ground and tyre clearance for small wheel bikes such as folders and kids’ bikes.

Shimano hasn’t made things too easy though, as it also has Essa, which now includes 8-speed components for drop bar bikes, although in 1x configuration only.

What is Cues?

Cues is already well-developed for mountain bikes and hybrids, with a range of 11-, 10- and 9-speed components. It looks to rationalise the groupset Tower of Babel that exists below Shimano’s 12-speed groupsets, where a 9-speed road derailleur won’t work correctly with 10-speed shifters or with 9-speed MTB components, for example, due to different designs and cable pull ratios.

Cues components are available in four series: U8000, U6000, U4000 and a new U3000, with the majority of the new drop bar components slotting into the U6000 and U3000 series. The entire Cues line-up is disc brake-only.

While Shimano’s 12-speed groupsets will continue to use its Hyperglide+ tech (or standard Hyperglide for 105/105 Di2), Cues uses Linkglide. This was initially promoted for electric bikes, to cope with their higher torque and riders’ tendency to shift under load. 

It has broader, more robust tooth profiles that Shimano says are up to three times as durable as Hyperglide+, although Hyperglide+ has faster shifting behaviour. Cues cranksets can still be paired with a Hyperglide chain.

Not only is Cues cited as a boon for riders who previously needed to find precisely the right part to replace a worn or damaged component, it is also claimed to allow bike workshops to carry a smaller range of replacement components and rationalise Shimano’s manufacturing and distribution. 

This should save cash for both Shimano and shops, although with 106 separate Cues components already listed on Shimano’s website, including ten different front mechs for example, even before the drop bar additions there’s still plenty of room for confusion. 

But for the rider, it should make it possible to upgrade a drivetrain piecemeal, rather than having to replace everything in one go. It doesn’t preclude electronic shifting either, as there’s already a Cues Di2 electronic system available for electric commuter and cargo bikes, although no Di2 products are announced for drop bars.

There’s more on Shimano Cues and its implications in our 2023 post covering the flat bar product launches. 

Drop bar shifters and new crankset options

Shimano says that its Cues drop bar shifter design is based on that of its 12-speed road groupsets and should be comfortable for a wide range of hand sizes. The 11/10-speed shifters are designed to work with a new flat mount hydraulic disc brake calliper, while the 9-speed shifters work with mechanical disc brakes.

The 9-, 10- and 11-speed components, including chains, cassette sprockets and jockey wheels are interchangeable, as they have the same sprocket spacing.

There are two 2×10 / 2×9-speed crankset options. The FC-U6040-2 double crankset is available in 50/34t and 46/32t configurations, with crankarm lengths of 170mm, 172.5mm and 175mm. There’s a second 2×10 / 2×9-speed option, called FC-U6030-2, with the same ratios available, but which adds a 165mm crankarm length.

There are also a pair of road/gravel 1x cranksets available, the FC-U6040-1 and the FC-U6030-1, which will work with 11, 10 and 9-speed Cues and have 42t or 40t options.

While there is still a range of crankset options, Cues adds just one new road front derailleur to the 10 options for MTBs and hybrids. It handles 10- and 9-speed shifting, although as it’s available in two versions, one for braze-on and the other for clamp fittings, that’s actually two more.

Below the Cues 6000 series sits the new 10- and 9-speed 3000 series. This includes 2x and 1x shifters and a brake-only lever for mechanical disc brakes rather than hydraulic. 

In addition, there’s a short cage rear derailleur for small wheeled 10- or 9-speed bikes. It’s designed to add extra ground and tyre clearance when used with 11-39t 10-speed or 11-36t 9-speed cassettes. There’s also a 140mm rotor for disc brakes for smaller wheels, as an alternative to the 160mm rotor that the rest of Cues is designed around.

Plus drop bar components for 1×8-speed Essa

Essa was launched as an affordable 1×8-speed groupset for MTBs and hybrids last year, but Shimano has now added drop bar shifters to the range. 

Strangely, Essa is based on Hyperglide rather than Linkglide. It works with a wide range 11-45t cassette, which can be used with any Hyperglide chain designed for 8, 7 or 6-speeds.

We reckon Shimano’s rationalisation of its lower spec groupsets should make things a little easier for riders and the adoption of Linkglide should lower maintenance requirements and costs for those who are more likely to use their bike as a tool or for leisure rides, rather than looking for peak performance. 

It may also help shake some costs out of budget bike production and maybe help a little to keep the lid on bike price inflation.
